content.question: A system consists of several interacting objects. One of the objects, Object O, is free to move only in the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math>-direction under the influence of only conservative forces, while the other objects are fixed in place. The potential energy of the system as a function of Object O’s position is <math alttext="U of x equals, k x raised to the fourth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>U</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is a positive constant. Can the motion of Object O be described as simple harmonic motion? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes. The displacement of Object O can be represented by a sinusoidal function of time.
Yes. The force exerted on Object O is in the opposite direction of Object O’s displacement from equilibrium.
No. The force exerted on Object O is not proportional to Object O’s displacement from equilibrium.
No. The total mechanical energy of the system does not remain constant while Object O is in motion.

content.answer: No. The force exerted on Object O is not proportional to Object O’s displacement from equilibrium.
